head.title: Mourning a Relative, and an Estate

hedline.hl1: Mourning a Relative, and an Estate

abstract.p: William Shaw letter on Stanley Herz's Sept 21 article defends estate tax

block.p: ''Rich? No, Frugal,'' by Stanley Herz (Op-Ed, Sept. 21), unintentionally demonstrates the virtues of the estate tax. One should evaluate a tax in comparison with other sources of government income. It is clearly more equitable to tax his in-laws' windfall stock market gains than, for example, to raise the already excessive tax burden on blue-collar workers.

''Rich? No, Frugal,'' by Stanley Herz (Op-Ed, Sept. 21), unintentionally demonstrates the virtues of the estate tax. One should evaluate a tax in comparison with other sources of government income. It is clearly more equitable to tax his in-laws' windfall stock market gains than, for example, to raise the already excessive tax burden on blue-collar workers.

Further, a tax is efficient to the extent that it does not discourage productive activities or encourage evasion. His wife's parents did not change their frugal behavior in light of the estate tax. The estate tax may not be good for Mr. Herz, but it is good for America.
